conclusion: Object A and Object B start moving from the same location in the same direction.

The image shows two velocity-time graphs, labeled as Object A and Object B. Both graphs start at the origin, indicating zero initial velocity. Object A's graph is a parabola, while Object B's graph is a straight line. The time points \\( t_1 \\), \\( t_2 \\), \\( t_3 \\), and \\( t_4 \\) are marked on the horizontal axis.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. It can be calculated as the slope of the tangent to the velocity-time graph at any given time.
At time \\( t_1 \\), the slope of the tangent to the velocity-time graph for Object A represents its acceleration.
At time \\( t_1 \\), the slope of the tangent to the velocity-time graph for Object B represents its acceleration.
To determine if the accelerations are the same, we need to compare the slopes of the tangents at \\( t_1 \\) for both objects.
Since the slope of the tangent at \\( t_1 \\) for both objects is the same, the acceleration of both objects at time \\( t_1 \\) is the same.
